title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: Our route to church was a lane calledWindmill Lane, which had many stables in it; thislane is bisected by a cross street called WindmillStreet, at the eastern end whereof there is a junctionof several streets, of which the narrowest and dingiestis the Potterrow. At the top of the Potterrow is alane at the back of the College, which led to anotherlane called the Horse Wynd, which descended to theCowgate. Right across the Cowgate is the Fishmarket Close, the top of which debouched on theHigh Street, but near the top of the close was a stairleading to the Parliament Close or Square immediately at the end of the High Church or St Giles'.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Thence he reeled and staggered through the Parliament Close, and got downthe back stairs, which have now disappeared, often stumbling by the way,and thus got into the Cowgate, some of the town-guard being close afterhim. He crossed the Cowgate, ran up the Horse Wynd, and proceeded along thePotterrow, the crowd all the way covering his retreat, and by this timebecome so numerous, that it was dangerous for the guard to look after him. In the Horse Wynd there was a horse saddled, which he would have mounted,but was prevented by the owner.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: He crossed the Cowgate, ran up the Horse Wynd, and proceeded along thePotterrow, the crowd all the way covering his retreat, and by this timebecome so numerous, that it was dangerous for the guard to look after him. In the Horse Wynd there was a horse saddled, which he would have mounted,but was prevented by the owner. Passing the Crosscauseway, he got into theKing's Park, and took the Duddingstone road, but seeing two soldierswalking that way, he jumped the dyke and made for Clear Burn.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17

title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: He conceived it to be his duty to set Robertson on hisfeet again, "and covered his retreat as much as possible from the pursuitof the guard." Robertson ran up the Horse Wynd, out at Potter Row Port,got into the King's Park, and headed for the village of Duddingston,beside the loch on the south-east of Arthur's Seat. He fainted afterjumping a dyke, but was picked up and given some refreshment.

title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Volume 1
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: He conceived it to be his duty to set Robertson on hisfeet again, "and covered his retreat as much as possible from the pursuitof the guard." Robertson ran up the Horse Wynd, out at Potter Row Port,got into the King's Park, and headed for the village of Duddingston,beside the loch on the south-east of Arthur's Seat. He fainted afterjumping a dyke, but was picked up and given some refreshment.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: Dugald Stewart, a contemporary and friend ofMackenzie, and the biographer of Dr.Stewart ° ^Robertson, lies not very far from AdamSmith in the Canongate Church-yard, near the southwest corner, under a large altar tomb of gray stone. He lived in Lothian Hut in the Horse Wynd, Canongate, upon the site of which a brewery now stands,and he died at No. 5 Ainslie Place, in the NewTown, in a house on a little square at the west end ofQueen Street, surrounded by aristocratic private residences. He was a constant frequenter of Creech's,although he had, naturally, no association withRamsay, who died when Stewart was a boy of tenstudying at the High-school, and living in the precincts of the University, of which his father was professor of mathematics.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: 28 LITERARY LANDMARKS OF EDINBURGH" Douglas " was first produced upon the regularstage on the 14th of December, 1756, at the Canongate Theatre (of which there is no sign now), in Playhouse Close, 200 Canongate. According to tradition, however- — and very misty tradition — it wasperformed privately some time before at the lodgings of Mrs. Sarah Warde, a professional actress,who lived in Horse Wynd, near the foot of the Canongate, and with the following most astonishingamateur cast :Lord Randolph. .Rev. Dr. Robertson [principal ofthe University of Edinburgh]. Glenalvon  Dr. David Hume [historian].

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: The White Horse continued to bea coaching house until the close of the eighteenthcentury, and in Boswell's day it was one of the best-hostelries in the town. It must not, however, beconfounded with The White Horse Inn, a picturesque ruin, with its shattered gables, its brokenchimneys, and the date 1523 over its window, stillstanding at the foot of White Horse Wynd, at theother end of the Canongate. This is one of themost antique buildings left in Edinburgh, and itwas the lodging -place of Captain Waverley "instirring '45."

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: The auctioneers and pawnbrokers had their quarters in the Horse Wynd, where I remember genteel families living in most excellent houses.* The potters and candlemakers congregated in the Eows which still bear their names. I don t know the former seat of the shoemakers, but about the beginning of the century they took possession of the new made Leith Terrace, which was then thought a very fine thing, as well it might, being the only

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: and the Horse Wynd, and up to the Central Office, where heinquired for me. I stared at the trim lad standing before me,and looking so fresh and happy and knowing, but the recognition did not come.

title: Redgauntlet :
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " So well, my good Mr Fairford, that I come hither determined to renew my acquaintance with one or two old friends, and with you in the first place. I halt at my old resting-place you must dine with me to-day at Paterson's, at the head of the Horse Wynd it is near your new fashionable dwelling, and I have business with you."
